security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill that provides guidance on using the ast-grep tool. It contains no executable code, network calls, or file system access. The skill is purely informational and describes how to use an external command-line tool for code analysis.

content.user_title: Search and refactor code with AST patterns
content.value_statement: Traditional text search misses code structure. AST-Grep finds and transforms code using syntax-aware patterns that understand your code's meaning.
actual_capabilities: Search code using AST patterns instead of text
Create custom linting rules for code quality
Batch refactor code across entire projects
Test code patterns before applying changes
limitations: Pattern syntax requires learning AST structure
Complex rules need testing before application
Works on local files only, no remote repositories

use_cases.title: Find deprecated API usage
use_cases.description: Search entire codebase for deprecated function calls and automatically replace them with new APIs.

use_cases.title: Enforce coding standards
use_cases.description: Create custom rules to detect anti-patterns and ensure consistent code quality across teams.

use_cases.title: Migrate code patterns
use_cases.description: Automate large-scale code migrations like updating imports or changing function signatures.

best_practices: Always test patterns on sample code before applying to entire codebase
Use specific AST node kinds to narrow search results
Back up code before performing large-scale refactoring
Document custom rules for team knowledge sharing
anti_patterns: Using text search when AST patterns would be more accurate
Applying untested rules to production code
Not using stopBy: end for relationship rules

faq.question: Is ast-grep compatible with all programming languages?
faq.answer: ast-grep supports 30+ languages including JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Go, Rust, Java, and more. Full list available in documentation.

faq.question: What's the difference between ast-grep and regular grep?
faq.answer: Regular grep searches text patterns. ast-grep searches syntax patterns using Abstract Syntax Trees, understanding code structure.

faq.question: Can I integrate ast-grep with my CI/CD pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, ast-grep works great in CI/CD. Use it for automated code quality checks, security scanning, and enforcing coding standards.

faq.question: How do I create complex search patterns?
faq.answer: Start with simple patterns, test incrementally. Use the playground at ast-grep.github.io/playground to visualize and debug patterns.

faq.question: Is ast-grep safe to use on production code?
faq.answer: Yes, but always test rules on backups first. Use --dry-run flag to preview changes before applying them.

faq.question: How does ast-grep compare to ESLint or other linters?
faq.answer: ast-grep complements linters. While ESLint has built-in rules, ast-grep excels at custom pattern matching and large-scale refactoring.
